But the reason that we've done this is that, going back about 20 years or so, Mount Vernon did a self-study in a variety of topics and basically asked our visitors, you know, what they would like to know more about.
And they told us a lot of things.
One of them was that they were interested in learning more about slave life at Mount Vernon.
So this comes from actual research on people who came.
Maybe tell me a little bit about the people who you see as your audience or people you reached out to to come to a place like Mount Vernon.
Well, Mount Vernon is the single most-visited historic site in the country.
We get more than a million visitors a year.
And so that's - you know, we've got one of the broadest audiences that you can possibly have.
And so you know, that's the folks - those are the folks that we're aiming this at.
And we realized that, you know, people come to places like Mount Vernon for different reasons.
Some come really to be educated and want to know a lot of in-depth information.
Others just come because it's a pretty place.
And so we realized that this is not necessarily going to be everybody's cup of tea.
But for those who are interested in the topic, we're trying to do the best we can to give an in-depth story of what life was like here.
Dennis, that's story can't just include the cabin.
What else do you have going on in terms of outreach, lectures or docent programs, anything like that?

Well, I mentioned that, you know, it was 20 years ago that Mount Vernon just really realized that we needed to talk more about this topic and since then, the cabin is really kind of the last thing among a variety of programs that we have developed.
Back in 1962, actually, Mount Vernon was one of the first sites to set up a slave quarter here up near the mansion, where we interpret the daily lives of the house servants who lived in that area.
And so this cabin is kind of a logical culmination of having that building because it tells the story of the daily lives of the field hands.
We have tours.
We've been giving slave-life tours here for the last 12 or 14 years when we've just finished the new museum building that has a gallery that's devoted to slavery at Mount Vernon.
You're not, however, doing reenactments with people dressed as slaves.
I bring that up because some places have, and it's been incredibly divisive in some cases.
Some people say, oh, this is great.
This is what's needed to bring things out into a really dramatic context.
Other people say, you cannot do this; this is crazy.
Other people say, well, this is soft peddling.
It wasn't even this easy for people who were enslaved.
How do you address the issue of whether or not there should be any kind of reenactment-style approach to this?
Well, you're absolutely right.

That's the kind of thing that really brings out, you know, a lot of emotions, rightfully so I'm asking, you know, one of our African-American interpreters to take on the role of an enslaved worker, you know, that's something that a lot of them, I think, respond to, you know, with a lot of ambivalence.
And so - and certainly, on the part of visitors, I think you're absolutely right.
There are some folks who feel that that's really the logical culmination of this and that if you don't do that, you are kind of, you know, pulling back from the hard reality.
But it's a difficult thing and I'm - we're not saying that we're never going to do that.
And we certainly do have several black interpreters on our staff who are willing to talk about slavery.
What we've not done so far and I don't know if we will in the future is to ask them to really do a living history impersonation of an enslaved worker.
Just briefly, are you making outreach to black communities to try to get them to come to Mount Vernon?
Well, we have.
And, of course, we're very near Washington D.C.
and so we have a number of programs working with the Washington, D.C.
schools where we bring school groups out here for a variety of programs.
We do have a fairly active community of African-American folks around Mount Vernon including a number of people who can trace their descent back to Mt.
Vernon slaves.
And so when we dedicated the cabin last month, we had invited two of them to come and to share their feelings about it.
Well, Dennis, thanks a lot.
My pleasure.
Thanks for asking me.
Dennis Pogue is associate director for preservation at George Washington's Mount Vernon Estate and Gardens in Virginia.
